review.title: A Flexible Coupling Approach to Multi-Agent Planning under Incomplete Information
review.abstract: Multi-agent planning (MAP) approaches are typically oriented at solving loosely-coupled problems, being ineffective to deal with more complex, strongly-related problems. In most cases, agents work under complete information, building complete knowledge bases. The present article introduces a general-purpose MAP framework designed to tackle problems of any coupling levels under incomplete information. Agents in our MAP model are partially unaware of the information managed by the rest of agents and share only the critical information that affects other agents, thus maintaining a distributed vision of the task.

metadata.title: A Flexible Coupling Approach to Multi-Agent Planning under Incomplete Information

sections.text: Agents solve the MAP tasks by introducing an iterative refinement planning process using one-agent planning technology. Specifically, agents will develop refinements through the paradigm of partial planning, a flexible framework for creating refinement plans that leaves unresolved details open, which will gradually be complemented by new refinements. Our proposal is supported by the introduction of a fully functional MAP system, and we show various experiments when applying our system across different types of MAP problems, from the most closely related to the most loosely coupled. Keywords: Planning & scheduling; Multi-agent systems

sections.heading: 2. Background
sections.text: Our MAP model is based on multiple single-agent planning techniques. This section provides an overview of the most important single-agent planning concepts used in our MAP approach, as well as the most relevant and recent approaches for collaborative MAP. We also outline the most relevant work on MAP architectures and frameworks and conclude with a summary of the most important contributions and innovations to our approach.

sections.heading: 2.1. Single-agent planning
sections.text: Retail planning has made great strides in recent years, particularly in the construction of domain-independent heuristics, but nowadays it is possible to find a wide variety of planning systems. Recent planners combine various techniques to increase the efficiency of the algorithms: Landmarks (Richter and Westphal, 2010), Domain Transition Graphics (Helmert, 2006), Forward Planning (Coles, Coles, Fox and Long, 2010), Probes (Lipovetzky and Geffner, 2011), Domain Transition Graphics (Helmert, 2006), Partial Planning (Coles, Fox and Long, 2010), Temporary Planning (Lipovetzky and Geffner, 2011) or Partial and Conquest Strategies (Dréo, Savéant, Schoenauer and Vidal, 2011).

sections.heading: 2.2. Cooperative Multi-Agent Planning
sections.text: The idea is that the idea is a project that seeks to organize itself in a way that underpins its objectives and objectives: the coordination of planning activities and the distribution of information in a common environment in which the information is distributed. The definition emphasizes two aspects of MAGPs that are not present in retail planning: the coordination of planning activities and the distribution of information between individual actors. The solution of a cooperative MAGP task involves the following stages (Durfee, 2001): 1) global task distribution, 2) task distribution, 3) pre-planning coordination, 5) post-planning coordination and 6) plan execution. Some of the previous stages can be avoided or combined: Some works explicitly do not distribute the goals (Level 2) (Belesiotis).

sections.heading: 2.3. Architectures and frameworks for MAP
sections.text: The design of architectures and frameworks is another active field of research in MAP. In recent years, some relevant work has been published in MAP frameworks. Work in (Wilkins and Myers, 1998) presents a complete MAP architecture for large-scale problem solving that organizes agents into planning cells committed to a specific planning process. TAEMS's domain-independent coordination framework (Lesser, Decker, Wagner, Carver, Garvey, Horling, Neiman, Podorozhny, Prasad, Raja et al., 2004) offers planning capabilities to agents and applies the GPGP approach to coordination. Other MAP architectures are based on universal MAS platforms rather than being designed from scratch. MAS platforms such as Magentix2 (Fogués, Alberola, Such, Espinosa and Garcia-Fornes, 2010; Argente, Botti, Carrascosa, Julian and Rebollo, 2011 or JAP platforms such as Foxinosa, 2010 and JAP-INabilines, 2010.

sections.heading: 2.4. Contributions of our model
sections.text: Our novel approach to collaborative MAGPs can be placed in the research trend that integrates planning and coordination; the MAP system achieves two main objectives: 1) it solves complex, highly interconnected problems and loosely coupled problems without losing generality; and 2) it enables heterogeneous actors to work with incomplete information by passing on only critical information that concerns other actors, and in part ignoring information from other actors about the MAP task. Our MAP approach focuses on a novel method that combines single-agent planning technologies and a refinement-based methodology. More specifically, we combine a distributed refinement planning process (Kambhampati, 1997) and individual sub-planning (Nguyen and Kambhampati, 2001; Younes and Simmons, 2003).

sections.heading: 3. Motivating example
sections.text: This section introduces the example MAP scenario, which we use below to illustrate the concepts presented in this paper. An example of the application, presented in Figure 1, describes a transport and warehousing scenario in which two agents (Ag1 and Ag2) assume the role of transport agencies and a third agent (Ag3) manages a warehouse facility. Transport agents deliver packages through a network of cities. In turn, the warehouse agent is responsible for storing and delivering packages to trucks. Packages can be either raw materials or end products. Agents in the MAP task are entrusted with two different objectives: the delivery of the end product to the city cA and the raw material p3 to the city cE. This scenario includes bi-directional links between cities that allow transport agents to move from one city to another. Transport agents can perform three different actions: they can deliver packages in the city p1 and unload them, and they can unload packages in the city cA.

sections.heading: 5.2. Concepts on Partial-Order Planning
sections.text: Our MAP model can be seen as a multi-stakeholder planning framework for refinement, a general method based on refinement of all possible plans (Kambhampati, 1997).A broker proposes a plan that typically enforces some of the goals that have not yet been supported (see Definition 5); then the remaining brokers work together to refine the plan by solving some of these pending goals in a plan. In this way, brokers solve the MAP task cooperatively by fine-tuning an initially empty plan one after the other. In this context, the Partial Planning (POP) (Barrett and Weld, 1994) presents itself as an appropriate approach to refinement planning, focusing on the gradual resolution of the pending goals. Consequently, brokers in our MAP approach plan concurrent actions by adopting the POP paradigm. Below, we provide some basic definitions regarding the one-broker POP and its adaptation to an MAP context.

sections.heading: 6. Planning language for MAP tasks
sections.text: In our MAP system, we define planning activities through multiple specification files. These files encode the agent's information about the MAP task, namely, the variables, Vi; the objects associated with the variables, Oi; the planning activities that are not included in classical, centralized planning. Planning activity in our MAP model can be considered a single-agent problem requiring only one central planning activity. MAP presents new requirements and challenges that are not included in classical, centralized planning. Planning activities in our MAP model can withhold their private information and decide what information is to be shared with the rest of the agents.

sections.heading: 6.3. Encoding example
sections.text: This MAP task describes a transport and storage scenario in which two agents (Ag1 and Ag2) act as transport agents and one agent (Ag3) manages a warehouse facility. Transport agents deliver packages through a network of cities, while the warehouse agent stores and loads the packages in trucks. Below, we describe the agent's domain and problem files for this task, emphasizing the specification of divisible information. Planning agents are given two distinct description files, namely the domain and problem file. The domain file contains a general description of the agent's capabilities, including the actions the agent can execute, and the predicates and functions he can manage. All agents of the same type share the same domain file, e.g. transport agents Ag1 and Ag2 in this example, receive the same domain file. The problem file models the specific problem assigned to each agent, including a specific task description, the specific object and the source file.

sections.text: This section summarizes the main stages of the MAP algorithm, followed by the agents to develop, share and select Refinement Plans with a solution for the MAP task. Agents follow a process that integrates planning and coordination so that agents solve both closely related and loosely coupled problems without losing the general public. Agents perform an individual partial order planning (POP) to build refinements over the current base plan, while one of the agents oversees the process of capturing the new refinement plans and selecting the next base plan. sections.heading: 10. Experimental results
sections.text: In order to evaluate the performance of our MAP system, several tests were performed comparing the MAP model with a one-agent approach to analyze its advantages and disadvantages compared to a centralized planning model. We used two different planning areas for our experiments. In the next subsections, the MAP areas are presented and the results of the various tests are analyzed.

sections.heading: 10.1. Multi-agent planning domains
sections.text: The two planning areas used to test the MAP system were taken from real problems or adapted to known case studies; the two areas were designed so that we could test the performance and quality of the solutions achieved with a wide range of problems; we tested our MAP system with varying degrees of complexity: from loosely coupled problems, where interactions between actors are rather low, to highly related problems, which require a strong coordination effort to be solved; in addition, we created both a multi-agent and a single-agent version for each problem; in Section 3, we described a transport and warehouse area where actors take on the roles of transport agencies and warehousing facilities that work together to transport raw materials and end products to different cities; this area leads to highly related problems, as interactions between actors are required to achieve the different goals; transport representatives have different capabilities, so they should cooperate to achieve the different goals.

sections.heading: 10.1.1. Picture domain
sections.text: This domain, adapted to the case study in (Parsons, Sierra and Jennings, 1998), represents a situation where multiple employees must work together to hang a series of images on walls, by acquiring various tools scattered across multiple sites. Agents move through the locations to get the tools and hang the images. The domain defines a set of bidirectional links that connect the sites. Figure 7 shows an example of this planning domain. Unlike the transport domain, agents in the image domain share the same skills: agents can pick up and drop a tool in the place where the intermediary and the tool are placed; an agent can also pass the tool he carries to another agent in the same place; agents can go from one place to another through the link that connects both sites; after all, an agent can hang and drop an image in a specific place with the tool he carries. This domain leads to the job agent having loose access to most of the goals, as the problem itself is likely to be solved by dividing the individual problems in a separate way.

sections.text: The following subsections show the experimental results. We performed two different tests.1 The first compares the quality of the solution plans produced by a single agent and a group of planning agents working together on the problem. To this end, we defined a number of MAP problems and the one-agent equivalent version. Finally, we measured the robustness and scalability of the MAP system by repeating a planning problem several times and increasing the number of planning agents in the system each time.

sections.heading: 11. Conclusions
sections.text: This article presents an MAP model that enables agents to plan under incomplete information. Our approach is also suitable for solving a wide range of MAP problems, from closely related problems with a high degree of interaction between agents to simpler, loosely coupled problems that have limited interactions between agents. Our model allows heterogeneous agents with different information, skills and private goals to create a common plan while addressing an incomplete view of the MAP task. Agents retain their private data and share only the relevant information for their interactions with other agents, making them unaware of some of the information managed by the rest of the agents.

metadata.abstractText: Multi-agent planning (MAP) approaches are typically oriented at solving loosely-coupled problems, being ineffective to deal with more complex, strongly-related problems. In most cases, agents work under complete information, building complete knowledge bases. The present article introduces a general-purpose MAP framework designed to tackle problems of any coupling levels under incomplete information. Agents in our MAP model are partially unaware of the information managed by the rest of agents and share only the critical information that affects other agents, thus maintaining a distributed vision of the task. Agents solve MAP tasks through the adoption of an iterative refinement planning procedure that uses single-agent planning technology. In particular, agents will devise refinements through the Partial-Order Planning paradigm, a flexible framework to build refinement plans leaving unsolved details that will be gradually completed by means of new refinements. Our proposal is supported with the implementation of a fullyoperative MAP system and we show various experiments when running our system over different types of MAP problems, from the most strongly-related to the most loosely-coupled.
